Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Evaluating the Contributions of Horizontally Transferred Bacterial Genes and Endogenous Duplication Events to the Diversification of Diatoms
Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project is to identify the sources of novel diatom traits, which have contributed to their extraordinary metabolic and species-level diversity. Some traits are encoded by genes acquired from distantly related bacteria, an entirely different kingdom in the tree of life. Other genes appear to have been generated by processes acting within diatom genomes. This project will generate genome-scale data for 250 phylogenetically disparate diatom species. These data will be used to: (1) infer evolutionary relationships, (2) identify the sources - whether intrinsic or extrinsic - of new genes, and (3) correlate the pattern and timing of gene acquisitions with the origins of novel traits.

This study would result in the training of a post-doctoral researcher, undergraduates and graduate students. With an estimated 200,000 species, diatoms are one of the most diverse groups of marine and freshwater phytoplankton. These microscopic "plants" play a major role in the global cycling of carbon and oxygen, producing the oxygen for one of every five human breaths. They manufacture the fatty acids that make their way up the food chain, eventually into fish, which humans harvest for fish oils. Diatoms possess a broad range of novel traits that, together, have facilitated their rise to prominence in the world's oceans. Ultimately, this project will reveal how nature has assembled the mosaic genomes of one of the world's most diverse and ecologically important lineages.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Diatoms are a group of hyperdiverse group of some 100,000 species of unicellular algae. They are found throughout marine and freshwater ecosystems where, like plants, they capture the sun?s energy to perform photosynthesis, creating energy sources that form the base of aquatic food webs and generating some 25% of Earth?s oxygen. Despite their diversity and global importance in the cycling of carbon and oxygen, many unanswered questions remain about how this lineage rose to such prominence. The major, overarching question addressed by this research was: What factors have driven the diversification of diatoms? Specific questions were addressed by building and using large phylogenetic trees (similar to family genealogies) of diatoms. Results showed that changes in reproductive biology, cellular motility, and transitions between marine and freshwaters have all played important roles in diatom diversification. Transcriptome data (all of the transcribed genes in the cell) were generated for nearly 200 diverse diatom species, tripling the number of diatom species with genome-scale data. These data were used to calculate the first genome-scale reconstruction of the diatom phylogeny and show, more generally, the impacts of different analytical approaches on phylogenetic inferences. These data were also used to test whether, throughout their history, diatom genomes have been impacted by genome duplication, a process by which genomes double (or more) in size by duplicating all of their genetic material. This project showed the first genomic evidence that genome duplication has, in fact, occurred regularly over the course of diatom evolution. The genome of one diatom species and its co-occurring bacteria were sequenced to test whether diatoms have exchanged genes with bacteria, as has been reported previously. Results showed that this diatom genome contained numerous genes that likely originated from bacteria through a process known as horizontal gene transfer. In sum, diatom genomes have acquired novel genetic material both through intrinsic (genome duplication) and extrinsic (acquisition of foreign bacterial genes) sources. Analyses of diatom organelle genomes showed that the plastid and mitochondrial genomes have likely been impacted by horizontal gene transfer as well. Thus, diatoms have pieced together an amalgam of genes from many different sources, resulting in highly chimeric genomes.

The large amount of genome-scale data generated through this project will be a valuable resource for research communities spanning many disciplines, including genomics, evolutionary biology, and marine science.

This project provided research experiences for numerous graduate and undergraduate students. These experiences included training in advanced molecular biological techniques and applications of computer programming and high performance computing to process and analyze large genomic datasets. The project also provided numerous public outreach opportunities about diatom biodiversity.
